author: timbeiko
content: Friendly reminder for the Flat DB call in 23 hours üôÇ

author: hudsonjameson
content: A group of us (Pooja, Tim B., James H., and I) had a chat about Berlin and we would like to have some async discussions before this Friday's ACD meeting. I'm going to post 3 messages after this one. Emoji signal agreement or disagreement with thumbs up/down and please elaborate in comments if you disagree:

author: hudsonjameson
content: 1. Do we agree that all of the EIPs that succesfully pass YOLOV3 + [EIP-2565: ModExp Gas Cost (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2565)] can go into Berlin? That includes any EIP listed in this specs link as going into YOLOv3 (https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/tree/master/client-integration-testnets) + EIP-2565.

author: hudsonjameson
content: 2. Are client teams comfortable with implementing the list from YOLOv3 in 2-4 weeks of dev time?

author: hudsonjameson
content: 3. Are all teams comfortable with moving forward with EIP-2537? If there are concerns about the implementation or security of EIP-2537 that will cause a significant amount of more testing time, we need to know ASAP so we don't have that EIP delaying Berlin.

author: holiman
content: For 3), I'm more in favour of evm384 over 2537. How do others feel?

author: timbeiko
content: For me, it depends on how quickly we can get 2537. If we can get it in Berlin and 384 is still for the next fork, I'd much rather have both and provide some extra security for the eth2 deposit contract asap.

author: timbeiko
content: If there are still "months" of testing to do on 2537 and there's no way it makes Berlin anyways, then there's no point in pursuing both.

author: _shemnon
content: Is there something wrong with 2537 or do you like the 384 solution better?  Why not both?

author: tkstanczak
content: we will implement and go with whatever others agree on, I would love to eip-2935 in as weel but understand that it may be late for changes

author: _shemnon
content: 2935 seems contradictory.  Because clients don't want to store the blockhashes we will move it into the state and make them do it anyway?

author: holiman
content: I thought the two were overlapping, and rather pointless to do both 2537 and evm384. If we add a precompile, it's there forever in the codebases

author: timbeiko
content: <@!211091239112671234> duplication of code aside, how is the fuzz testing for the precompile coming along? Security-wise are you satisfied by 2537 or are there still outstanding issues?

author: holiman
content: I know of no issues at the moment. Am I satisfied that there are none? No, but I probably never will be ü§∑

author: holiman
content: We've been focusing our fuzzing on 2929 lately, not so much 2537

author: prestwich
content: we've been fuzzing 2537 & 2539 for a while. happy to share results

author: holiman
content: Yes please do share, details about the set-up and execs would be great

author: prestwich
content: Was planning to do a 5 minute update at ACD on Friday. Is that soon enough?

author: holiman
content: Maybe a gist or repository ? So one can check the actual fuzz-testing framework?

author: prestwich
content: <@!381789485777682434> put it together. https://github.com/shamatar/algebraic_fuzzer

author: prestwich
content: my modifications for eip2539 are over here: https://github.com/prestwich/algebraic_fuzzer

author: prestwich
content: generally speaking, it's aware of the structure of the curves, generates valid and invalid test cases, and compares the output of the go and rust implementations

author: shamatar
content: Still there are no final performance results on evm384 across all the clients, as well as there is no consensus versus what it should be compared. Without this data and any estimate about completion I don‚Äôt see why 2537 should be delayed. I‚Äôm also grateful to James who spends extra resources on a white box fuzzing of 2537. Black box should have found crashes, here we can check arithmetic edge cases explicitly

author: shamatar
content: Also, an idea of ‚Äúsponsoring‚Äù evm384 that was once mentioned (increase the block limit, I don‚Äôt remember the author unfortunately, may be it was mentioned during one of the last calls) makes a dangerous precedent, and is there even a way to do it? Like make storage 10x more expensive and bump block limit 10x, so everything stateless is cheaper?

author: timbeiko
content:
Here is the agenda for this Friday's AllCoreDevs: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/219

<@!619357961923330051> I've added a bullet about 2537 fuzzing üëç

author: shamatar
content: Instead I‚Äôd propose to extend current white box fuzzing to also include an ‚Äúold‚Äù BN254 and establish a standard, that e.g. EC crypto implementation should do N steps of fuzzing using this procedure to be nominated as proper quality for inclusion?

author: geratbb
content: Hello! I was wondering if anyone knows if it is possible to compile EVM bytecode (or an easily decompilable language like Solidity) to LLVM IR? Please let me know if you are aware of how this can be done, it would be extremely useful for my research project.

author: lightclient
content: <@!737415405223805009> etc labs has an evm-llvm project: https://github.com/etclabscore/evm_llvm

author: geratbb
content: <@!543900561460822016> I am using that as part of my project! From what I understand, and please correct me if I'm missing something, but this project is an LLVM backend which essentially translates LLVM IR into EVM bytecode. In other words, it is agnostic to the frontend language so long as it can be compiled into LLVM IR. To complement this I'm looking for a frontend which can turn EVM bytecode into LLVM IR so that I can do: smart contract byte code -> LLVM IR for analysis -> instrumented smart contract byte code. Does that make sense?

author: lightclient
content: <@!737415405223805009> ah sorry, misread your message. Have you looked at SOLL? I believe it supports Yul -> LLVM -> wasm https://github.com/second-state/SOLL
